image.altText: Interior gallery with wooden floor and white wall with large textile work in shape of Tasmania in floral stitched fabric.

props.synopsis: "Dangerously low" arts sector funding has rendered the Tasmanian industry "highly vulnerable", with funding stagnant since 2016-17, the state government has conceded.

title.children: 'Major reputational risk': Briefing gives warning to Tasmanian arts minister

image.altText: An old man with a mask and scarf, two young women and another gentlemen with a face covering walk into a court building.

props.synopsis: After former teacher Keith Athol Bates-Willie was found guilty of assault against Hobart schoolboys, 10 complainants read out in court their victim impact statements as sentencing begins.

title.children: 'He robbed me': Victims-survivors of Hobart teacher speak out

image.altText: A photo from the March for Australia rally in Hobart.

props.synopsis: Pauline Hanson's daughter Lee stood unsuccessfully at this year's federal election for a Tasmanian Senate spot but continues to be a keynote speaker at anti-immigration rallies. Airlie Ward takes a deep dive with investigative reporter Paddy Manning.

title.children: TassieCast: Is this part of a One Nation succession plan?

image.altText: Two climbers dressed in black on top of a rock pillar.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian wilderness retrievals are rarely straightforward, and now the teams involved in some of the state's most complex rescue efforts have been awarded at a national level.

title.children: Seacliff climb, freezing trek and river amputation earn national rescue awards

image.altText: A sunset view of an ocean, with a boat and still water.

props.synopsis: Unseasonable temperatures have lasted along the eastern seaboard for weeks — which has Sydney, and possibly Brisbane, on track to observe their warmest October on record.

title.children: Two of Australia's capital cities on track for warmest October on record

image.altText: An older man in military uniform.

props.synopsis: Australia's defence force has had discussions with the Unted States to provide support for its Gaza peace plan but the government says no formal request has been made yet.

title.children: Defence in talks to assist Gaza peace plan but Australia says no request yet

image.altText: Ace Frehley on stage with his guitar and signature KISS makeup

props.synopsis: The original lead guitarist of the glam rock band captivated audiences with his elaborate makeup and smoke-filled guitar.

title.children: Ace Frehley, founding member of rock group KISS, dies at 74

image.altText: Workers in hazmat suits outside a post office.

props.synopsis: Authorities are working to identify the chemical that leaked from a single package at two post offices in Queensland. Four people of the people who were taken to hospital earlier have now been discharged.

title.children: Five people taken to hospital after chemical leak in Australia Post offices

image.altText: A man wearing a grey and black hooded jumper captured on CCTV

props.synopsis: A man who was missing in Victoria's east for more than a week is recovering in hospital after being found in bushland when he started a fire to draw attention to his location.

title.children: Missing man found alive in bushland after lighting fire to signal for help

image.altText: A Palestinian man with a beard sits unsmiling in a chair.

props.synopsis: Shadi Abu Sido spent 18 months in Israeli detention believing that his entire family had been killed in Gaza. Then he was reunited with his wife and children in Gaza.

title.children: 'That scene was indescribable': Shadi Abu Sido returns home to Gaza after months in prison

image.altText: Batter players off his pads into the leg side, watches where the ball goes, along with the slip fielder behind

props.synopsis: Former Australia batter Nic Maddinson has revealed he underwent chemotherapy for testicular cancer.

title.children: Australia Test batter Nic Maddinson reveals testicular cancer diagnosis

image.altText: A BHP Group logo is displayed on their building

props.synopsis: The resolution of negotiations between Australian mining giant BHP and China's state-backed iron ore buyer China Mineral Resources Group could reshape not just the resources industry, but also international trade flows, global markets, and the relationship between China and the West.

title.children: What are BHP and China fighting over and why does it matter for Australia?

image.altText: A screenshot of a black and white image of blazing boat on an ocean with the word 'unclassified' above it.

props.synopsis: A US strike against a suspected Venezuelan drug-smuggling vessel has left multiple survivors, as Venezuela's ambassador to the United Nations condemned the strikes as a "series of assassinations".

title.children: US strike on suspected Venezuelan drug boat 'extrajudicial executions'

image.altText: F1 driver Oscar Piastri holding a winner's trophy over his head after winning a grand prix

props.synopsis: "Papaya rules" have dominated Formula 1 for two seasons, but with both McLaren drivers in the heat of a world championship battle, Oscar Piastri and Lando Norris may no longer prioritise what is best for the team.

title.children: Team orders are out of the window, Oscar can now play by 'Piastri rules'

image.altText: john Bolton dressed in dark suit and red tie speaking at a lecture with pen in his right hand

props.synopsis: Donald Trump's former national security adviser has been charged with storing top secret records at home and sharing classified information. Here's what we know.

title.children: Who is John Bolton and why has he fallen out with Trump?

image.altText: A skull lies among artefacts from World War Two under the water of Chuuk Lagoon in Micronesia.

props.synopsis: The Federated States of Micronesia's biggest tourism asset has become one of its largest threats, with as much as 22 million litres of oil from World War II shipwrecks slowly leaking into the ocean.

title.children: Micronesia's worst fears realised as WWII shipwrecks leak

image.altText: A white woman, short blonde hair, wearing glasses, white blazer and blue top. Standing in front of blurred green background

props.synopsis: Northern Territory Attorney-General Marie-Clare Boothby says the changes will protect freedom of expression and religion while retaining protections against hate speech.

title.children: NT passes anti-discrimination law changes to 'restore' free speech, religion

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market falls after a downbeat session on Wall Street, weighed down by a sell-off across US regional bank stocks. Gold jumped to a new record high, above $US4,300 an ounce, as investors flocked to safe haven assets amid US-China trade tensions. Follow live.

title.children: ASX slips as gold surges to new record above $US4,300

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Australia's blowout in house-building times hits WA hardest
Developed market sovereign debt rises rapidly: Fitch Ratings

props.synopsis: There is general agreement in Labor that Jim Chalmers is the government's best communicator. But insiders watching this race know Tony Burke is the master tactician.

title.children: Race between Chalmers and Burke pits communicator against tactician

image.altText: AI child abuse phone generic

props.synopsis: A senior academic has warned a Sydney school caught up in an investigation into digitally altered explicit images of female students is just "another shocking iteration" of gendered violence.

title.children: Academic's warning on explicit AI images amid Sydney schoolgirls report

image.altText: A small dog sits in a carry bag in an airport terminal.

props.synopsis: The first pet-friendly commercial flights have taken off in Australia this week. Here's what you need to know about the new service.

title.children: Pet-friendly flights are taking off in Australia. Here's what to know

image.altText: Fish eye still of dog running to attack

props.synopsis: A behavioural veterinarian says there's not usually one direct cause for dogs attacking, and owner education could help improve the rate of horror incidents.

title.children: As dog attacks continue to make headlines, what rules exist for owners?

image.altText: A large brown bear, dripping with water, emerges from a river.

props.synopsis: At least seven people have been killed by bears in the country since April and many more have been injured as the hungry animals venture into human territory to find food.

title.children: Bears kill record number of people in Japan amid scores of attacks

image.altText: A man leans over the back of a machine that looks like it is used to break rocks. It sits in a large coal pit.

props.synopsis: The receiver of a WA coal mine says it is ramping up operations in a final attempt to trade out of insolvency before millions of dollars in taxpayer support dries up.

title.children: Insolvent WA coal miner insists it has years, if not decades of life left

image.altText: Photo of Gus

props.synopsis: SA Police and ADF personnel have concluded a four-day renewed search for four-year-old Gus, as a missing persons advocate speaks out about the emotional impact of such cases on all families who have experienced the disappearance of a loved one.

title.children: Expanded search for Gus ends as missing persons advocate speaks out

image.altText: An Indigenous man shakes hands with King Charles in a grand hall. Other Indigenous men standing nearby.

props.synopsis: King Charles marked the major milestone in Aboriginal land rights alongside Uluru-Kata Tjuta's traditional owners.

title.children: King Charles marks land rights milestone in first visit to London's Australia House

image.altText: A NZ rugby league player grimaces as he runs the ball and is tackled by two Toa Samoa players in an international match.

props.synopsis: Emerging superpowers Samoa and Tonga will field formidable teams loaded with NRL talent in the third edition of the Pacific Championships.

title.children: NRL stars embrace their island heritage as Pacific Championships loom

image.altText: Zach Merrett high fives fans walking through the race

props.synopsis: The AFL trade period offered three different test cases on just how much value a first-round pick holds during negotiations. Two stars got their moves, while one was left stranded.

title.children: Merrett trade saga shows it is time to stop using first-round picks to judge deals

image.altText: Close-up of an adult powerful owl showing its huge yellow eyes

props.synopsis: It's that time of the week again. Test your news knowledge to see how much you remember for the week that was.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: A deported star, a shock retirement and the hottest place on Earth

image.altText: An artist's impression of riverside site with right rise buildings and a park.

props.synopsis: The government says construction could begin from March 2027 and has suggested the site could feature over 4,000 homes, as well as "event lawns" and promenades.

title.children: Brisbane riverside site to be transformed with potential for thousands of homes

image.altText: Night shot with a flash lighting up a fluffy white, brown and grey coloured bat in freeze frame over a water body as it drinks.

props.synopsis: Artificial roosts, or "bat boxes", have become a popular home conservation tool. But a new study raises concerns about the danger these boxes pose during heatwaves.

title.children: Boxes for bat conservation become deadly roosts during heatwaves

image.altText: In the golden light of a dusty evening, is a silhouette of man in hat on horseback leading cattle.

props.synopsis: Hamish McIntyre is named the new president of Australia's peak farmer representative body.

title.children: New president to take the reins at troubled National Farmers' Federation

image.altText: A tall building of units on a suburban street.

props.synopsis: Renters and experts are calling for change in one of just two Australian jurisdictions where renters can be evicted for no reason and the only place where landlords can raise rents more than once a year.

title.children: Renters urge reform of nation's 'worst' tenancy laws in 'landlord's market'

image.altText: A man holds two casts of skulls in each hand and smiles at the camera

props.synopsis: A new study claims lead might be the reason why Homo sapiens came to dominate the world.

title.children: New research claims lead was causing headaches even in ancient times
